ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

OPENING OF VEHICLE QUOTA TENDERS
(Viewing by public)


    1. Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng asked the Minister for Communications if his Ministry will allow the public to view the opening of tenders for Certificate of Entitlement.

     The Minister of State for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan) (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry welcomes the public to view the opening of the vehicle quota tenders.

    Since the vehicle quota system was implemented in May last year, the opening of the tenders at the Registry of Vehicles (ROV) has been witnessed by representatives of the media, and officials from the Auditor-General's Office and also my Ministry.

    The entire procedure for conducting the vehicle quota tenders has been audited and approved by the Auditor-General.

     Dr Wang Kai Yuen (Bukit Timah): Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister consider reducing the time period between the opening of the tenders and the announcement of the result? Or to go even one step further, would the Minister

Column: 674

consider announcing the results first, subject to confirmation?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the time period at the moment is about 10-12 days. Part of the reason is that there is a large number of tenders to process. The banks will also have to process the drafts to make sure that they do not bounce and that the amounts are correct. All in all, it takes about 10-12 days.

    We will ask the ROV to consider reducing the time period but in so far as releasing the preliminary results of the tenders is concerned, the Member will appreciate that doing so would mean that the preliminary results and the final results would vary. How much the variance will be, we are not sure. It depends on what sort of checking procedures have been instituted. But I will ask the ROV to consider releasing the preliminary results if there are no other repercussions involved.

CONVERSION TO WEEKEND CARS
(Rebate on Additional Registration Fee)


    2. Dr John Chen Seow Phun asked the Minister for Communications whether a rebate on the Additional Registration Fee will be given to those who wish to convert their normal cars to weekend cars.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, when Government agreed to allow existing cars to convert to weekend cars, we had two choices when considering what rebate to give. The first choice was a pro-rated refund of the net Additional Registration Fee (ARF) and import duty. The second choice was an enhanced rebate on the road tax. We decided on the latter scheme. In lieu of a refund on ARF, we decided to give a 95% rebate on road tax, in other words, 25 percentage points more than the 70% for new weekend cars. The reason why we opted for road tax rebate was that it was simpler to administer and also fairer to the motorist.

    Let me explain. The net ARF of a car is the ARF less the lump sum PARF value. For many of the older cars, the ARF paid could be either equal to or even lower than the lump sum PARF value. So if we had opted for the first

Column: 675

option, these car owners would end up getting very little or even no rebate of the ARF and import duty. They would then only enjoy the 70% rebate on the road tax. So under the second option that we finally decided on, they would enjoy a 95% rebate on road tax.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun (Hong Kah GRC): Sir, since the Minister thinks that the first option is administratively more burdensome, I would like to ask whether, in order to increase the attractiveness of the scheme and to benefit more Singaporeans, he would consider allowing weekend cars to go on the road, except the CBD, during weekdays, say, from 11.00 am to 3.00 pm without having to pay for the labels?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, what the Member is suggesting is that we extend the hours whereby the weekend cars are eligible to be on the road. The fundamental purpose of the weekend car scheme is to allow more Singaporeans to own a car and at the same time make sure that they do not use it at certain times which would congest the road further. Our present study shows that these so-called off-peak hours where congestion will be much less are in the evenings and on weekends. It does not include those hours that the Member suggested just now.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Sir, I believe the congestion during those periods ---

     Mr Speaker: Dr Chen, no speeches, ask your question.

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: Yes, Sir. The Minister said that during those hours ---

     Mr Speaker: What is your question, Dr Chen?

     Dr John Chen Seow Phun: I am asking whether it is true that the roads are congested during those hours. From what I know, it is only in the CBD. That is why I am asking whether he will consider allowing cars to be on the road, outside CBD, during weekdays and from 11.00 am to 3.00 pm.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, it is extremely difficult to say that during these hours,

Column: 676

there is no congestion outside the CBD. I think all of us would have experienced congestion during these hours at one time or another. The point I am trying to make is that, for a start, for the weekend car scheme to work, we would have to demonstrate that it is attractive enough for Singaporeans to want to own a car and at the same time not use it to the extent that it clogs up our roads. For those hours that the Member is suggesting, PWD statistics show that there is a certain amount of congestion, perhaps not as much as during the peak hours, but certainly not enough for us to warrant extending the hours of usage at the moment.

Column: 676

ADDITIONAL REGISTRATION FEE
(Further reduction)


    3. Dr John Chen Seow Phun asked the Minister for Communications whether he will consider a further reduction of the Additional Registration Fee to better allow market forces to determine the price of owning cars since the vehicle quota system is now working well.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan (for the Minister for Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the vehicle quota system has been effective in controlling the growth in vehicle population. The quota premium reflects the price that car buyers are willing to pay for the ownership of a vehicle given the present rate of taxes for ARF, customs duty and road tax.

    If we reduce the Additional Registration Fee for cars further, the reduction will most likely result in higher quota premiums. For buyers of new cars, this will, on the average, make little difference because the increase in COE prices will be offset by the reduction in ARF. However, owners of old cars who wish to extend their COEs will have to pay much more because the prevailing quota premium would now be much higher. This would be disadvantageous to owners of the older cars.

    My Ministry will monitor the situation carefully and we would like to see how the quota system works under different economic conditions before changes that would severely affect the quota premiums are introduced.

Column: 677

LATE NIGHT NEWS
(Telecast)


    4. Mr Chin Harn Tong asked the Acting Minister for Information and the Arts (a) whether the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation will telecast shortened news programmes later in the evening for those who miss the earlier programmes and (b) whether, as an alternative or in addition to the repeat news programmes, the SBC will consider having a news-by-telephone service for persons without access to the teletext service.

     The Acting Minister for Information and the Arts (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Singapore Broadcasting Corporation had late night news bulletins until 1989. This was discontinued due to low viewership. The demand could not justify the considerable resources needed to produce and telecast such late night news.

    The late Chinese news over Channel 8, for example, was watched by about 21,000-43,000 viewers, while the news at 8.00 pm in Chinese would commonly draw 435,000 viewers in 1989, which is about 5%-10%. As for the English news, which was telecast over Channel 12, it drew 1,000-3,000 viewers compared to news at 9.00 pm on Channel 5 of about 96,000 viewers in 1989.

    SBC has alternative sources of news in SBCText and in its various radio services for those who want to keep in touch with the news. SBC will, however, continue to monitor interest in the late night TV news and reinstate them if the demand justifies the resources required for this.

    As for news by telephone service, there is really no need for this as listeners can easily tune in to radio for the news. There are late news bulletins on our various radio channels.

    Head Q (cont.) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [15th March, 1991],

    "That the total sum to be allocated for Head Q of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100." - [Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam].

    Question again proposed.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Sir, when we adjourned I have not had the opportunity to answer the remainder of Dr Arthur Beng's question on civil defence. If I may now take them up. He had asked about the plans for reservists. The answer is that we consider the reservists to have very important roles in all aspects of civil defence, for example, the public warning system, the shelter programme and I would say that in all CD operational units they are made up of reservists and we saw how important a role they played in the Hotel New World rescue operation. We are also very pleased with the dedication and enthusiasm of the CD reservists when we had the Baguio earthquake. Many of them rang up to volunteer although we had, because of time, already despatched a mission to Baguio. The organisation, as Dr Arthur Beng knows, is formed to division, constituency and zone units.

    As far as training is concerned, most of the existing reservists have served in the SAF or the Police but they are given conversion training for their CD roles and also specialised training and upgrading. For example, we have several upgrading courses and programmes. We have introduced a Section Commander course to upgrade reservist private to the rank of corporal to hold section commander appointments. We have some 1,680 of them. We have also a Platoon Commander course to upgrade reservist NCOs to hold appointments of platoon commanders. And the graduands are given the rank of sergeant. There are some 1,100 of them. There is also the Reservist Officer course for Platoon Commander course graduands found suitable for upgrading to the officer rank. We have some 150 reservists appointed as Second Lieutenants.

Column: 679



    What of the future? Because of the importance we attach to the reservists, we must have better training programmes. For this, I am glad to announce that a new training academy will be built at a site in Jalan Bahar at a cost of some $62.9 million. This academy will have basic, advanced and refresher training facilities for reservists, regulars, NCOs and others. It will have purpose-built facilities, like a special ruins area, a high tower for high-rise fire fighting, and areas for heavy plant training. Construction is expected to start this year, and I hope it will be completed by 1994. At the same time, camps which now exist in Nee Soon, Hougang and Jalan Bahar will be upgraded.
12.45 pm

    Dr Arthur Beng also asked about the role of volunteers in the constituencies vis-a-vis reservists. The volunteers at the constituency level play an indispensable role and they will have to work hand-in-hand with the CD reservists in a real emergency. I say they are indispensable because if a disaster occurs, in peace time or in war time, they will be the first at the scene. They know the residents and the residents know them. So they will be instrumental in bringing about a certain calmness, prevent disorder and chaos, and even attend to basic roles such as first-aid evacuation before the specialised rescue teams arrive. To demonstrate the importance of volunteers in the constituency, they are involved in most of the important civil defence exercises, including the large scale community spirit exercises. I hope I have answered his questions.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Tang Guan Seng): Sir, there were two points raised by Dr Arthur Beng last Friday which have not been replied. Can I reply to him now?

     The Chairman: Yes.

     Mr Tang Guan Seng: Sir, the Chairman of the GPC on Home Affairs touched on the development of civil defence centres in constituencies last

Column: 680

Friday, and he would like to know how the Ministry can assist the Civil Defence Coordinating Committees (CDCCs) in setting up such centres.

    The decision of whether to set up CD centres should be left to the CDCCs themselves. It depends on the advisers, the CDCC leadership and the needs of the constituency. In some constituencies, the CDCCs, especially the active ones, want to have their own centres or offices. Some constituencies have already set up their own CD centres. More will be set up in the next few months. On the other hand, some CDCCs feel that it is more convenient to make use of the facilities of the community centres, education centres and senior citizens' clubs for their activities. Many of these CDCCs have financed the running cost and equipment themselves. For those who want to set up their own CD centres in void decks, we have in fact got the approval of HDB to offer rents at a concessionary rate on the same basis as social, educational and community services provided by the CCCs and the RCs, ie, only $1.30 per square metre.

    Sir, the Ministry will ask the SJCDF to look into what assistance can be given to CDCCs to set up their own CD centres. For example, to provide a start-up capital grant and assist in fund raising activities. In particular, we shall ask the SJCDF to consider earmarking some of the funds raised through walkathons and other events for this purpose.

    Sir, the Chairman of the GPC on Home Affairs, Dr Arthur Beng, also proposed that the SJCDF run a common operations room for emergency and non-emergency cases. It is an interesting proposal. I would like to thank him for bringing this up. But before we come to a firm decision, we have to consider carefully the following implications. The SJCDF is an emergency organisation. Its mission is to save lives and protect property in emergencies. I am not sure at this point that the SJCDF should widen its role to cover non-emergency functions. Currently, the public can dial "995" for the Emergency Ambulance Service. All "995" calls are received at

Column: 681

the operations room. But if the operations room also handles non-emergency calls, an emergency call may be delayed because the lines are jammed up by the non-emergency calls. The delay in getting through may mean life or death. The emergency service is responsible for sending patients to hospitals for urgent medical attention.

    Sir, the Chairman of the GPC has pinpointed the problem and that is the public perception with regard to Emergency Ambulance Service. I hope that through our sustained public education programme, we can rectify this wrong perception.

    Coming back to Dr Arthur Beng's proposal, I appreciate his interest and concern on this matter. However, the top priority of the Emergency Ambulance Service is to save lives, and it is right that the limited resources of the Service should be put to effective use.

    Sir, the Ministry recognises the importance of the complementary role played by the private ambulance services and therefore welcomes any improvement made to the services. The SJCDF is prepared to help a private organisation set up a separate operations room for private ambulance services on a commercial basis.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Sir, I would first like to clarify that when I made the proposal regarding the joint operations room for the ambulance service, I referred only to emergency cases. I did not in my speech in any way refer to non-emergency cases. If I may quote my own speech, I said "in subscribing to a joint emergency ambulance operations room". Sir, I am not in any way suggesting that SJCDF should deal with non-emergency cases.

    Sir, I am glad to hear from the Minister that the Police Force has indeed done a good job. And it is heartening to note that for the first time in the last 10 years there has been a drop in seizable offences for two consecutive years, in 1989 and 1990. The Ministry and the Police Force must be congratulated.

    The GPC is also heartened to note that the Police Academy will be taking a

Column: 682

much wider role. The GPC has been in discussion with the Ministry for the last two years regarding the future role of the Police Academy, and we are glad that some of our recommendations have been included.

    Sir, regarding CD reservists, it is important that the Police and the Civil Defence reservists who are outside the SAF orbit also be given all the recognition that the SAF reservist has been given. And as the Minister has not touched on this, I wonder whether he would further elaborate whether the RECORD Committee's recommendations will also apply to reservists under the Ministry of Home Affairs.

    Regarding CD volunteers, I am sure that their morale will indeed be boosted in knowing that they have an important role to play, for there is some confusion on the ground with CD reservists coming on line as to what is the role of the volunteers vis-a-vis the reservists, and we have heard the Minister clarify this point.

    Before I go on to my next item, maybe the Minister would like to clarify.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Sir, as I said just now, both in the Police and in the CD, the reservists play an important role in the SJCDF as the 60,000 or so reservists form the backbone of our CD's rescue capability. I agree that because the reservists have served with distinction and enthusiasm, and because they form an important and integral part of the Police's and CD's mission, we must recognise their contributions. The Home Affairs Ministry will give attention to the management of reservists. A Home Affairs Reservists' Committee has been set up comprising Police and Civil Defence reservists and it has been meeting and obtaining feedback on reservist matters since last year.

    As far as the RECORD Committee's recommendations are concerned, this is another area which is being looked into. I can say that my Ministry fully supports the RECORD Committee's recommendations on the setting up of separate associations for Civil Defence and Police reservists. I think this association will

Column: 683

help to build up the identity and the esprit de corps among the Home Affairs' reservists.

    I also agree to the recommendation to have a SAFRA-type of clubhouse to cater to the recreational needs of these reservists. I think they should be of the scale and scope of the latest SAFRA clubhouse. I hope this new clubhouse will be ready in three to five years' time if we obtain the necessary approval for land and funds. Meanwhile, I have instructed my Ministry's officials to look into the prospect of a temporary clubhouse for our reservists.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Sir, may I refer now to item (d) - National Registration.

    Sir, the Ministry has announced its plans to issue credit-card type identity cards. The issue of the new identity cards will indeed be a massive exercise. What is the time-table and plan for the exercise to issue the new identity cards? Will convenient centres be set up both at the population centres and in the workplace, eg, in the central business district? This is important because some may find it more convenient to go during office hours and others may find it more convenient to go after office hours, and thus a site near their homes may be more convenient. Will there be mobile teams that can visit factories or other establishments where there are large groups of people?

    Sir, regarding the new identity cards, firstly, is the data to be captured any different? Secondly, what are the new advantages of this new identity card? Thirdly, should one lose this new identity card, what will be the replacement cost?

     Mr Tang Guan Seng: Sir, the new identity card conversion exercise, which would take three years, is scheduled to start on 3rd June this year. In all, 2.62 million new identity cards will be issued during this exercise. As this is one of the biggest exercises launched by the Government, second only to the population census, my Ministry will make sure that it will run smoothly.

Column: 684



    Sir, I want to assure the House that the exercise will be made convenient for the public. The conversion exercise will be conducted on a constituency by constituency basis. The whole island has been divided into five zones - Central, East, North, West and South. Each zone has an average of 16 constituencies. One registration centre will be set up in a community centre of each constituency. All the constituencies in the zone will be covered before the registration team moves to another zone. The exercise will be launched first at MacPherson Community Centre in MacPherson Constituency. This constituency has been selected because it has only about 17,700 NRIC holders, the smallest number in the Central Zone.

    NRIC holders who are aged 18 and above as at 1st January this year will need to change their ICs. They will receive notification letters which will state the community centre and the dates to report. The letters will be sent one month in advance. Two weeks before the teams start work at the community centre, NRIC holders in the constituency will receive a personal particulars form. The form will tell them of a specific three-day period when they can go to the CC to change their ICs. The team will be stationed at a community centre for seven days a week, except during public holidays. The opening hours for registration will be from 10.00 am to 10.00 pm, even on Sundays.
1.00 pm

    Sir, as the Chairman has suggested, there should be an additional registration centre in the city for the convenience of office workers. We will have such a centre in the city, possibly near an MRT station. The opening hours will be from
11.00 am to 7.00 pm from Mondays to Fridays. It will benefit office workers in the central business district.

    To ensure the smooth running of the conversion exercise, new ICs will be issued at this centre only to those notified by the National Registration Office to re-register.

    As for those who lose the new ICs, they will have to pay a fee, that is, for the first time, $20. For subsequent replacement, the rates will be higher. This is to remind the holders that the IC is a very important document. They should take good care of their ICs.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Sir, I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for the details. It is heartening to note that the first replacement cost will be $20 and not something more phenomenal than that. Of course, we do not encourage people to lose their ICs.

    May I just ask for one point of clarification. You are giving the person three days to register. What if he happens to be away and is not able to make it during that three days? Will he then have to defer to the next zone's period, or can he still get a new date in his own constituency?

     Mr Tang Guan Seng: Sir, for those who are unable to go to the centre to register within that three-day period, if an explanation is given, he can go to the NRD headquarters.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Sir, may I turn to item (e) - Drug Rehabilitation and Recidivism.

    Sir, in 1974, Singapore experienced the start of the heroin epidemic. The situation peaked in 1977 when the heroin

Column: 686

population was estimated to be 13,000. Since then, Singapore has been one of the few countries in the world to make drug rehabilitation compulsory, while still treating the drug offender as a patient and not as a criminal.

    Sir, I understand that two years ago, the Ministry started a new therapy programme: The Short, Shock and Sharp programme. In this programme, selected first and second drug offenders were put through an intensive two-week rehabilitation programme. Will the Minister please comment on the results of this programme and the problem of recidivism and relapse?

    Will the Minister also give the House an update regarding the problem of drug trafficking?

    Sir, the drug tragedy does not only affect the offender. It is a tragedy that affects the whole family, including the innocent ones, the spouse and the children. The aim of drug rehabilitation is not only to take the patient off drugs, but to be able to assimilate him back into society. Often, the long separation from the family for rehabilitation, extending between two and two and a half years, can make this transition back to society difficult. There may have been some instances of family break-ups and problems with the children.

    The drug centres are already having day release programmes, and have also established "half-way" homes. However, there is no place like home, and no better "balm" for the patient than to be with his family. To facilitate this transition, will the Ministry consider allowing the "good-risk" drug offenders, that is, those the professionals have said as having a good chance of succeeding, early release by introducing new surveillance measures, such as the use of electronic tags or bracelets? Yes, this is not a fail-safe system as some have mentioned, as the patient may be consuming drugs even in his own home. The whole idea of these tags is that the patient will have to be indoors by a certain hour each evening. However, if we combine electronic surveillance with drug testing and counselling, perhaps early release will be possible and family

Column: 687

disruption minimised. Ironically, with electronic surveillance, instead of becoming less personal, drug rehabilitation may take on a more human face with early release being possible.
